newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore scientists invent secure Internet system.
newsitem.headline: Singapore scientists invent secure Internet system.

text.p: A group of Singapore scientists said on Tuesday they had invented a secure system for financial transactions on the Internet.

The system would allow individuals and businesses to deal directly with banks via the worldwide computer network, said Lam Kwok Yan, spokesman for a group of researchers at the National University of Singapore (NUS).
"We have developed an infrastructure which allows people to have secure communications and financial transactions over the Internet," Lam, a senior computer science lecturer at NUS, told Reuters.

He said the new system, developed by the NUS team in collaboration with several banks for Singapore at a cost of Singapore $500,000 (US$355,000), used smartcard technology which allowed the transmission of hidden digital signatures.
Lam said the system, which uses Microsoft's Windows 95 operating system, should be fully completed and ready for use by sponsoring banks by March 1997.

Sponsors of the new system include Singapore's four large banks -- Development Bank of Singapore, Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp Ltd, Overseas Union Bank Ltd, United Overseas Bank Ltd -- as well as Singapore Telecommunications Ltd and Citicorp's Citibank.
The "cryptography", or secret writing, used by the system protected security codes from unauthorised access and prevented hacking. This allowed safe use of credit card data, he said.
Lam said he hoped the system could be used in future for home banking or even for trading on the world's financial markets via the Internet.
